Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Membership in organization engaging in subversion by force
Crimes.Application_Facts: Haqi was a member of KDPI, which engaged in violent acts against governments including civilian and military targets.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicant for immigration or refugee protection
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenged Board's jurisdiction and interpretation
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether the Board had authority to interpret IRPA provisions on subversion
Crimes.Evidence_Used: KDPI’s history of violent actions and organizational objectives
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board found Haqi's justification under international law unconvincing
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Deemed inadmissible due to membership in subversive organization
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certification of question or overturning of decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: KDPI engaged in subversion by force; membership sufficient for inadmissibility regardless of individual intent or temporal involvement
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration laws
Crimes.Violation_Type: Membership in organization engaging in subversion by force
Crimes.Application_Facts: Haqi’s membership in KDPI, an organization conducting armed opposition against Iranian government
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Immigration applicant with alleged ties to banned organization
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Challenge to Board’s interpretation of 'subversion by force'
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of Board’s authority in interpreting IRPA security provisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Record of KDPI’s violent activities and political aims
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claims of lawful resistance not accepted
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Maintained inadmissibility based on organizational affiliation
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation consistent with precedent and statutory language
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Affiliation with group using force to undermine government constitutes non-compliance with immigration law

Crimes.Crime_Name: Membership in an organization engaging in subversion by force
Crimes.National_Security_Element: Engagement in violent acts aimed at overthrowing a government
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Threat posed by transnational armed organizations
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: KDPI’s use of violence against state institutions and civilians
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Membership in group designated as subversive under Canadian immigration law
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Armed attacks, insurgency, and attempts to destabilize government
Crimes.Leadership_Role: No indication of leadership role; general membership cited
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Board relied on documented history of KDPI activities
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Whether membership alone triggers inadmissibility despite claimed humanitarian motives
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of organizational conduct and declarations
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s justifications not sufficient to rebut presumption from organizational conduct
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Lack of distinction between combatants and civilians in KDPI operations
Crimes.Governing_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 34
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Interpretation of 'subversion by force' in immigration inadmissibility context
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Permanent inadmissibility and denial of entry to Canada

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Minister's certificate alleging terrorist affiliation
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Federal Court review under s. 40.1 of the Immigration Act
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Assessed on balance of probabilities; included confidential intelligence and testimony
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Singh's denials were deemed incongruous and not credible
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Court must determine if there are reasonable grounds to believe membership in a terrorist organization
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Minister issued certificate based on security intelligence reports
Key_Evidence_Considered: Financial support to families of hijackers
Sheltering wife of former BK leader
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Denials presented but found not credible
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to challenge the certificate
Crimes.Outcome: Certificate upheld; Singh considered inadmissible under immigration law

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Affiliation with BK/BKI, a designated Sikh militant group
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat due to association with terrorist organization
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: High risk based on close associations and support activities
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Sustained contact with known militants and leadership figures
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Supportive and associative conduct indicating membership
Crimes.Target_Entity: Canadian national security and immigration integrity
Admission_or_Involvement: Sheltered wife of former BK leader
Received calls from Wadawa Singh Babbar
Had significant ties with BK/BKI leaders
Crimes.Leadership_Role: No formal leadership role established, but active supporter
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Court found applicant's explanations inconsistent and lacking credibility
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Credibility of Singh’s denials versus intelligence and circumstantial evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Denials deemed incongruous and not credible
Credibility_Factors: Lack of plausible explanation for contacts
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Challenge to ministerial certificate on judicial review
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Declared inadmissible; subject to removal from Canada

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Support for a proscribed terrorist organization
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Endangerment through material and logistical support
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Ongoing risk due to sustained connections and supportive acts
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Association with individuals involved in violent extremism
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Non-combat support including shelter, communication, and financial aid
Admission_or_Involvement: Provided indirect support to militant network
Crimes.Leadership_Role: Supporter without evidence of operational command
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Applicant’s explanations rejected due to inconsistency
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Weight given to classified evidence and behavioral patterns
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Denials lacked plausibility and coherence
Credibility_Factors: Actions consistent with support for militant cause
Crimes.Governing_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – terrorism-related inadmissibility
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of national security certificate
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Certified as inadmissible; threat to national security confirmed

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged complicity in crimes against humanity through association with LTTE
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Judicial review granted; inadmissibility under s. 35(1)(a) overturned
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Immigration Division decision reviewed by Federal Court
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Association with armed group linked to human rights abuses
Crimes.Credibility: Applicant's claims of non-violent advocacy found credible
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Alleged indirect support for crimes against humanity

Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Membership in organization linked to terrorism
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: TNA's collaboration with LTTE through intimidation and shared objectives
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Affiliation with TNA, an entity associated with LTTE
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Organizational support and alignment with terrorist goals
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Evidence of TNA-LTTE ties deemed credible
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Extent of TNA’s operational connection to LTTE
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and contextual evidence of organizational links
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Immigration Division's assessment upheld as reasonable
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Consistency of evidence on TNA-LTTE relationship
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Inadmissibility upheld based on organizational membership

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility on security grounds for being a member of an organization engaging in terrorism
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: LTTE involvement through employment with controlled entity
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Informal participation or support via employment
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Employment used as basis for alleged membership
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: IAD failed to properly assess credibility and context
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Employment history without analysis of intent or commitment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Insufficient evaluation by IAD
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, section 34(1)(f)
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Inadmissibility finding set aside; remitted for redetermination

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work under duress for terrorist-controlled entity
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether employment under duress constitutes membership in a terrorist organization
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: IAD failed to consider mitigating factors such as duress
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Crown to establish inadmissibility
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant’s claim of working to avoid front-line combat
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Membership requires more than mere employment; must show involvement and commitment to goals
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Error in law and fact regarding membership interpretation
Crimes.Defendant_Response: IAD maintained inadmissibility based on organizational link

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim with inadmissibility issue
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of voluntary membership despite forced association
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Judicial review initiated due to unreasonable assessment
Crimes.Protected_Group: Victims of forced recruitment by non-state armed groups
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Inadequate state protection against LTTE conscription
Crimes.Credibility: Applicant's account found plausible but not adequately weighed
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Low – inability of Sri Lankan government to prevent LTTE recruitment
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Ethnicity and geographic location making individual vulnerable to LTTE recruitment

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act subsection 34(1)(f)
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Reasonable grounds to believe organization engaged in terrorism
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Long-term membership in Amal, awareness of terrorist activities
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Claim of civil wing involvement lacked supporting evidence
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Lack of evidence distinguishing civil vs. military wing involvement
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claim not credible due to lack of corroboration
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) subsection 34(1)(f)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of IRB decision on inadmissibility

Crimes.Crime_Name: Being a member of an organization that there are reasonable grounds to believe engages, has engaged or will engage in terrorism
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Reasonable grounds to believe Amal engaged in terrorism
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Sustained association with Amal and knowledge of its activities
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Membership in a designated terrorist organization
Crimes.Target_Entity: Canadian immigration and national security system
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Admitted membership without proof of non-terrorist role
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Failure to substantiate limited involvement claim
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Absence of evidence for separation between civil and militant wings
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim of exclusive civil involvement deemed not credible
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) subsection 34(1)(f)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Challenge to administrative determination of inadmissibility

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Membership in an organization with a history of subversion or terrorism
Crimes.Application_Facts: Gebreab joined EPRP in 1986, after its violent phase in the 1970s; Board found EPRP to be a continuous organization
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Whether the correct legal test for organizational continuity was applied
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Historical activities of EPRP in the 1970s, organizational structure and continuity
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not central; focus on organizational continuity
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Inadmissible due to membership in EPRP
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Immigration Division's decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard for factual findings, correctness for legal test
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: EPRP considered a continuous organization that had engaged in subversion; membership triggers inadmissibility regardless of timing
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Membership in an organization engaging in subversion by force of any government
Crimes.Application_Facts: Gebreab joined EPRP in 1986 when it was not violent; Board found EPRP’s 1970s activities sufficient to classify it as subversive
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Correctness of legal test for organizational continuity
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Historical record of EPRP’s 1970s subversive activities
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Assessment focused on organization, not individual credibility
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Found inadmissible due to EPRP’s past subversive acts
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Correctness for legal interpretation, reasonableness for factual findings
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Organization’s past engagement in subversion is sufficient for inadmissibility, even if ceased before membership

Crimes.Crime_Name: Membership in an organization engaging in terrorism
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential risk due to association with terrorist organization
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Membership in organization previously engaged in terrorism
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Affiliation with EPRP, which committed terrorist acts in the 1970s
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Terrorist and subversive acts in the 1970s
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Board accepted historical evidence of EPRP’s terrorist activities
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Continuity of EPRP as an organization from 1970s to 1986
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and historical evidence of EPRP’s activities
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Focus on organizational conduct, not personal involvement
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Timing of membership relative to violent period
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Interpretation of 'engaged in terrorism' regarding organizational continuity
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Inadmissibility to Canada, judicial review dismissed

Application_Facts: Requirement for human resources management experience in staffing process; Mr. Agnaou lacked required experience and alleged discrimination; no data on under-representation of visible minorities provided
Procedural_Issue: Alleged abuse of authority and lack of procedural fairness in staffing decision
Evidence_Used: Staffing criteria, Mr. Agnaou's application history, tribunal findings
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of availability rate data to demonstrate adverse impact on visible minorities
Outcome: Tribunal's decision upheld; claims dismissed; costs awarded to Attorney General of Canada
Remedy_Sought: Setting aside of staffing process, declaration of discrimination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Abuse of authority, discrimination (direct and adverse impact) under Canadian Human Rights Act and Public Service Employment Act
Decision_Rationale: Insufficient evidence of adverse impact or under-representation; Mr. Agnaou had opportunities to gain experience; staffing process found lawful and non-discriminatory

Application_Facts: Applicant is a Tamil from Sri Lanka residing in Malaysia; claimed refugee status due to civil war and family losses; cited ongoing risks despite post-conflict conditions
Claimant_Status: Residing in Malaysia at time of application
Residency_Compliance: Lawfully residing in Malaysia as a foreign national applying from abroad
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review initiated to challenge visa officer's decision
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court exercising jurisdiction over immigration decision made abroad
Evidence_Used: Country condition reports on Sri Lanka
Applicant's personal narrative and family history
Travel records indicating mobility within Sri Lanka
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence demonstrating personal risk or fear of persecution upon return
Credibility_Assessment: Visa officer found applicant's fear of persecution not credible given ability to travel to Sri Lanka and improved security conditions
Decision_Outcome: Permanent residence application rejected under Convention Refugee Abroad and Humanitarian-Protected Persons Abroad classes
Relief_Sought: Overturning of visa officer’s rejection of permanent residence application
Legal_Standard_Applied: Eligibility under refugee or humanitarian grounds per IRPA sections 96, 145, 147
Decision_Rationale: No compelling evidence of personal risk or persecution; country conditions improved; applicant able to travel safely to Sri Lanka; no serious personal impact established post-conflict

Violation_Type: Failure to assess risk of torture
Application_Facts: Claimant presented evidence of visible scarring, past detention, and torture; US report indicated possible torture post-detention in Sri Lanka
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to properly analyze risk of torture; credibility errors in assessment
Evidence_Used: Visible scarring, testimony of past detention and torture, US country report
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider available evidence on risk of torture
Credibility_Assessment: Board made credibility errors in evaluating the claimant's testimony and evidence
Relief_Sought: Recognition of risk of torture under s. 97(1)(a); refugee protection
Remedy_Sought: Remand for reconsideration of risk of torture
Legal_Standard_Applied: Substantial grounds to believe danger of torture upon return
Decision_Rationale: RPD did not fulfill its duty under s. 97(1)(a) to assess torture risk despite credible evidence

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section related to procedural fairness under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status in Canada but was questioned on credibility due to undisclosed evidence (ERT43035.E) regarding Eritrean citizenship.
Procedural_Issue: Board relied on undisclosed extrinsic evidence without providing applicant an opportunity to respond, breaching procedural fairness.
Evidence_Used: Document ERT43035.E (undisclosed extrinsic evidence about Eritrean citizenship)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to disclose key evidence affecting credibility assessment
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's credibility was challenged based on undisclosed evidence
Decision_Outcome: Negative credibility finding by the Board
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination of the case by a different Board
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with heightened scrutiny due to procedural fairness concerns
Decision_Rationale: Use of undisclosed evidence violated procedural fairness, depriving applicant of fair hearing rights
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court (on review)

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical residency requirement
Application_Facts: Applicant was absent from Canada for significant periods due to overseas employment assignments; maintained some connections but did not centralize mode of existence in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Did not meet the 1095-day physical presence requirement within four years prior to application
Procedural_Issue: Review of Citizenship Judge's decision, analysis of errors, application of Koo Factors
Evidence_Used: Duration and pattern of absences from Canada, nature of employment abroad, ties to Canada (e.g., property, family, financial accounts)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failed to demonstrate that Canada was the center of his mode of existence despite maintaining some connections
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of the Citizenship Judge’s decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Koo Factors for assessing centralization of mode of existence
Decision_Rationale: Applicant did not satisfy the residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) and failed to show closer connection to Canada than to other countries

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee eligibility due to Internal Flight Alternative
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 97(1)
Application_Facts: Applicants fled Mexico fearing persecution due to past kidnapping and domestic abuse; claimed gender-related persecution
Residency_Compliance: Not applicable – claimants were outside country of nationality and seeking protection
Procedural_Issue: Fairness of hearing assessed; no procedural unfairness found
Evidence_Used: Credible evidence of past harm, including kidnapping and domestic abuse; country condition reports on Mexico
Evidentiary_Deficiency: None identified – Member accepted credibility but found IFA available
Decision_Outcome: Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) exists in Mexico City and Guadalajara
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Decision_Rationale: Despite credible claims of past harm and gender-based risk, applicants could relocate to safer areas in Mexico with access to state protection
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Refugee Protection Division

Violation_Type: Unreasonable denial based on presumed state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 96-97
Governing_Law: Canadian immigration law, jurisprudence on refugee protection, Charter of Rights and Freedoms where applicable
Application_Facts: Applicants are Roma from Hungary who claimed persecution and did not seek state protection due to belief in its ineffectiveness
Procedural_Issue: RPD selectively relied on evidence, ignored systemic failures, failed to properly assess applicants' subjective beliefs
Evidence_Used: Evidence of state protection mechanisms in Hungary
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Ignored counter-evidence of police inefficacy, lack of enforcement, and systemic discrimination against Roma
Credibility_Assessment: Applicants' belief in unavailability of effective state protection was not adequately considered
Decision_Outcome: RPD denied refugee status based on presumed access to state protection
Outcome: Federal Court overturned the RPD decision
Remedy_Sought: Reassessment by a new RPD panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution, inability to access effective state protection
Decision_Rationale: RPD's decision was unreasonable due to selective use of evidence and failure to engage with evidence of systemic failures

Legal_Provision_Violated: Duty of Fairness in Administrative Decision-Making
Application_Facts: Officer contacted Wu's employer without disclosing the communication or its contents to Wu
Procedural_Issue: Failure to disclose information used in decision-making
Evidence_Used: Undisclosed information obtained from employer
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of opportunity for applicant to respond to new evidence
Remedy_Sought: Remittal of case to a different officer for redetermination
Decision_Rationale: Officer violated procedural fairness by relying on undisclosed information, depriving Wu of the right to respond

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with section 16(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants corrected discrepancies during interview regarding education, addresses, and identity documents; alleged contradiction on military service not substantiated
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Application denied due to perceived credibility and settlement issues
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged lack of truthful answers under s.16(1)
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Credibility assessment conducted without sufficient evidentiary basis
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Discrepancies in application and interview responses
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence supporting contradiction on military service
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Unreasonable determination by Visa Officer
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Remand to a different visa officer
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Truthful answers and document submission under s.16(1) IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Visa Officer's credibility finding was unreasonable and unsupported by evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: False or misleading information in immigration application
Crimes.Violation_Type: Submission of allegedly false or misleading information
Crimes.Application_Facts: Minor discrepancies clarified during interview; no substantial contradictions found on military service or other key details
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Application rejected due to alleged untruthful responses
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged provision of false or misleading information
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Credibility determination made despite clarification in interview
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No concrete evidence of intentional misrepresentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Unreasonable assessment lacking evidentiary support
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Remand to a different visa officer for re-determination
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement to provide truthful answers during immigration examination
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Decision based on minor, clarified discrepancies; overall determination unreasonable

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 96-98
Application_Facts: Angela Bromberg claimed persecution in Uzbekistan based on her Armenian/Jewish ethnicity; she sought refugee status in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Compliant with Canadian asylum application procedures
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged inconsistencies in testimony affecting credibility
Evidence_Used: Testimony of Angela Bromberg
Supporting documents related to ethnic background and conditions in Uzbekistan
Credibility_Assessment: The Refugee Division found the claimant not credible due to contradictions in testimony, though minor
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a refugee in Canada
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Division's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution based on race, religion, nationality, etc.
Decision_Rationale: The Refugee Division’s credibility findings were reasonable; minor inconsistencies did not undermine the overall conclusion
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Officer's refusal to assess hardship or risk due to lack of nationality evidence
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 25
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, case remanded for reassessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant provided sworn evidence of identity; credibility not properly assessed
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Sworn affidavit, circumstantial evidence of identity and origin
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 25 IRPA – Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Risk of statelessness, hardship in Sierra Leone, long-term residence in Canada
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to assess humanitarian and compassionate factors despite uncertain nationality
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to conduct interview or assess risks/hardships
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Sworn evidence of identity and potential statelessness
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Humanitarian and Compassionate considerations under s. 25
Crimes.Application_Factor: De facto statelessness, ties to Canada, inability to obtain documentation from war-torn country
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable decision due to procedural unfairness
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged misrepresentation regarding border documents due to lack of verifiable nationality proof

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Officer's refusal to assess hardship or risk due to lack of nationality confirmation
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, case remanded for reassessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible evidence of Sierra Leonean origin dismissed without proper evaluation
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Supporting statements, contextual evidence of origin
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 25 IRPA – Humanitarian and Compassionate exemptions
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Origin in Sierra Leone, inability to obtain official documents, risk upon removal
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Officer failed to assess risks despite credible non-documentary evidence
Crimes.Application_Error: Dismissal of claims without interview or adequate assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence suggesting Sierra Leonean origin and associated risks
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Assessment of hardship and risk even with uncertain nationality
Crimes.Application_Factor: War-related loss of documentation, prolonged displacement
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Breach of procedural fairness, unreasonable conclusion
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Allegation of false representation based on unverified nationality claims

Crimes.Violation_Type: Misrepresentation and failure to consider protected humanitarian factors
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 25 IRPA – Duty to consider best interests of the child and H&C grounds
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status with evidence of hardship and risks to children
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Stateless or de facto national of Sierra Leone
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Long-term unauthorized stay in Canada due to documentation barriers
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Lack of definitive proof of nationality, not intentional fraud
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to conduct best interests of the child analysis
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Assessment of removal risks without confirming nationality
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Affidavits, country condition reports, evidence of family ties in Canada
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inability to produce formal nationality documents due to conflict in Sierra Leone
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible but unverifiable claims due to systemic documentation failures
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable decision, breach of procedural fairness
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Humanitarian and Compassionate consideration, protection from removal
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reassessment by a different officer with specific instructions
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the child, s. 25 H&C assessment
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer ignored credible evidence and failed statutory duties
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board / PRRA Officer

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Comply with Immigration Requirements
Crimes.Violation_Type: Non-compliance with documentation and procedural requirements
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 25 IRPA – Failure to assess H&C grounds and child’s best interests
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant unable to prove nationality due to trauma and lack of documentation
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Undocumented resident with de facto ties to Canada
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Irregular status due to systemic and personal barriers
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Perceived rather than proven intent to deceive
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Denial of interview, speculative assumptions about parentage
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Personal affidavits, circumstantial family and residence evidence
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Absence of birth certificate or national ID from Sierra Leone
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Consistent narrative undermined by lack of documentary proof
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Acceptance of Sierra Leone as country of reference or recognition of statelessness
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reassessment with updated guidelines and acceptance of alternative evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds, procedural fairness
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer speculated without evidence and ignored statutory obligations

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant admitted membership in CLA, which engaged in armed attacks against Namibia's government; minimal involvement and lack of knowledge claimed
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Admission of CLA membership, evidence of CLA’s subversive activities
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant credible but irrelevant due to focus on membership
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Membership alone sufficient for inadmissibility regardless of level of involvement
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Crime_Name: Being a member of an organization that there are reasonable grounds to believe has engaged in an act of subversion against any government by force
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat through association with subversive group
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Organization (CLA) engaged in armed attacks against foreign government
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Membership in organization involved in forceful subversion
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Armed attacks and subversion by force
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Relevance of applicant's knowledge or level of involvement
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Direct admission, organizational records, public reports
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found credible, but not determinative
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Consistency of testimony, lack of motive to lie
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Denial of entry to Canada, upheld on judicial review

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in failing to consider cumulative persecution and disbelieving the female applicant's evidence?
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court allowed judicial review and remanded for redetermination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board disbelieved wife's miscarriage claim despite no inconsistencies
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence, medical reports (lack of physical documentation)
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 97(1) IRPA - risk of torture or cruel and unusual treatment
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to Kurdish identity and refusal of military service
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to consider cumulative persecution and unsupported credibility findings
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to assess credibility reasonably and cumulatively evaluate incidents
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Alleged miscarriage due to beating, repeated detentions and abuse
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard of review for persecution claims is patent unreasonableness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Credibility findings reviewed if based on erroneous facts

Decision_Rationale: Frequent and prolonged absences from Canada
Significant personal and economic ties to Colombia
Pattern of absence inconsistent with residency requirement

Crimes.Legal_Standard: Confirmation of release under conditions that neutralize danger

Dispute_Type: Civil dispute over intellectual property rights
Legal_Issue: Whether the defendant's action can be stayed until resolution of a related case involving Cummings Point
Governing_Law: s. 50 of the Federal Court Act
Evidence_Assessment: Defendant sold the accused division prior to providing access to records or personnel; plaintiff retains right to examine defendant despite limited information
Burden_of_Proof: On defendant to demonstrate lack of access to necessary information
Legal_Rule: A stay may be granted under s. 50 of the Federal Court Act only if continuing the action causes prejudice or injustice to the defendant and does not harm the plaintiff
Standard_of_Review: Judicial discretion based on risk of prejudice or injustice
Grounds_for_Claim: Defendant sought stay to avoid duplicate proceedings
Outcome_on_Merits: Stay denied; defendant must proceed with discovery
Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of sale of accused division, availability of records and personnel
Defendant_Response: Requested stay of proceedings pending outcome of related case
Outcome: Stay denied; defendant allowed extended time for discovery arrangements

Legal_Issue: Whether the tribunal erred in dismissing the complaint regarding the use of a retracted reference
Evidence_Assessment: The tribunal found no evidence of unreliability or bias in the retracted reference
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate unreasonable decision-making
Credibility_Factor: Mr. Burke's retracted reference was assessed for reliability and bias
Legal_Rule: The tribunal must determine if the reference is sufficiently familiar with the candidate's work; abuse of authority includes bad faith or personal favoritism
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged abuse of authority due to reliance on a retracted reference
Authority: Attorney General of Canada (named as sole respondent)

Dispute_Type: Survivor's pension entitlement under the Canada Pension Plan
Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant raised an arguable case for judicial review of the PAB's refusal to grant leave to appeal
Evidence_Assessment: RT found contrary evidence credible, including financial independence and lack of knowledge about the deceased's background
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant failed to demonstrate errors or new evidence sufficient to justify judicial intervention
Credibility_Factor: Financial independence of the parties, lack of knowledge about deceased's background
Legal_Rule: An arguable case exists if new evidence or legal issues not considered by the RT are presented, or if errors in the RT's decision can be demonstrated
Grounds_for_Claim: Evidentiary errors by the RT, such as unaddressed letters and lack of cross-examination
Outcome_on_Merits: No reasonable basis to overturn the PAB's decision
Key_Evidence_Considered: Letters not addressed by RT, absence of cross-examination, financial independence, knowledge of deceased's background
Legal_Framework: Canada Pension Plan, Pension Appeals Board (PAB), Review Tribunal (RT)
Defendant_Response: PAB refused to grant leave to appeal the RT's decision
Legal_Provision: Provisions of the Canada Pension Plan regarding survivor's pension and common-law partnership
Authority: Pension Appeals Board (PAB), Review Tribunal (RT), Federal Court

Crimes.Legal_Rule: Compelling reasons must arise from previous persecution or torture
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of return to Burundi due to past trauma and risk
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimed risk in Burundi despite criminal inadmissibility
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Allowance of PRRA application or judicial review

Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Non-state actor (Hutu rebels in Burundi - claimed threat)
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Prior criminal activities leading to deportation
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Claimed past trauma and fear of persecution
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Officer found no current risk in Burundi
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Claimed targeted due to past involvement or identity
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant failed to meet burden of proof

Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Non-state actor (Hutu rebels in Burundi - claimed threat)
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Prior criminal record leading to deportation
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Claimed past trauma and fear of persecution in home country
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Moderate (property-related offense with potential for violence)
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Officer found insufficient evidence of ongoing risk
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Alleged danger from Hutu rebels upon return
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Claimed targeted due to identity or past experiences
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant did not provide sufficient credible evidence

Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer's decision to deny the application under section 25 of the IRPA is reasonable
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 25, Paragraph 117(9)(d)
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant was not declared due to unawareness; humanitarian grounds dismissed as generic
Decision_Outcome: Decision annulled, case remanded for reconsideration
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's unawareness of obligation to declare family member
Legal_Rule: Section 25 IRPA allows H&C considerations; Paragraph 117(9)(d) excludes undeclared family members
Grounds_for_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds, technical denial despite hardship
Outcome_on_Merits: In favor of applicant; original decision found unreasonable
Key_Evidence_Considered: Specific hardships faced by applicant, lack of awareness in declaration
Legal_Framework: IRPA, family class provisions, H&C discretion
Defendant_Response: Officer dismissed humanitarian grounds as common to all Haitians
Outcome: Judicial review granted, case referred back for reconsideration
